awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Validation of Constitutive and Numerical Modeling Techniques for Soil Liquefaction Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Soil liquefaction is a pervasive problem during earthquakes that has caused significant and costly damage to civil infrastructure in the US and other parts of the world.  Practicing engineers and academics have been using computational models and numerical simulation tools in the design and analysis of geosystems involving liquefiable soils.  These tools are highly sophisticated and refined, but they often have been revised following many major past earthquakes to incorporate the lessons learned from post-event observations and investigations.  Thus, the validity of these tools is yet to be fully established.  The Liquefaction Experiments and Analysis Projects (LEAP) is an international collaboratory to produce a set of high quality experimental data using centrifuge testing, and then to use these data to establish the validity and range of applicability of existing computational models and simulation procedures for soil liquefaction analysis.  The collaboratory includes centrifuge facilities at the University of California at Davis, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Cambridge University (UK), Kyoto University (Japan), NCU (Taiwan), Zhejiang University (China), IFSTTAR (France), KAIST and KWater (Korea), and HKUST (Hong Kong).  The project leverages the experimental resources at these facilities to complement the testing capabilities in the participating US institutions for investigating a number of challenging problems in which soil liquefaction plays a prominent role.

Three consecutive projects (LEAP-2017, -2018, and -2019) are planned which will be used to address three important issues: reproducibility and uncertainty; effects of soil fabric; and effects of biaxial ground motion on soil liquefaction.  LEAP-2017 will use improved quality control measures to minimize uncertainties, and an extensive testing program will be designed and conducted to characterize the sensitivity and uncertainty for relatively simple lateral spreading centrifuge tests.   LEAP-2018 will produce high quality centrifuge data to enable the assessment of the applicability of computational tools for predicting the influence of fabric and layering.  LEAP-2019 will assess the performance of numerical tools against a series of biaxial shaking centrifuge experiments using synthetic and real earthquake motions.  Following each LEAP, a workshop will be held to discuss the results of experiments and numerical simulations.  The data resulting from this project will be organized, archived and publically released using a new database publication mechanism.  The organized data will be useful for (1) future validation efforts, (2) other ongoing liquefaction research, and (3) in geotechnical modeling education. A number of graduate students are involved in the project and will receive unique training opportunities beyond the capabilities of any one institution alone.  A Validation Driver Framework (VDF) will be developed to allow modelers as well as practitioners to efficiently validate their codes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Soil liquefaction is a pervasive problem during earthquakes that has caused significant and costly damage to civil infrastructure in the US and other parts of the world. Practicing engineers and academics have been using computational models and numerical simulation tools in the design and analysis of geosystems that involve liquefiable soils. The tools are highly sophisticated and refined. However, the credibility of these tools has to be established through validation undertakings using experimental data. Such a validation is generally not feasible using records of earthquake case histories in view of the uncontrolled and uncertain experimental conditions during these events. The Liquefaction Experiments and Analysis Projects (LEAP) is an international collaboratory that produced a set of high-quality experimental data using centrifuge testing. The data was then used to assess the validity and range of applicability of existing computational models and simulation procedures for soil liquefaction analysis.

The undertaken research involved three LEAPs: (1) LEAP-UCD-2017 in which the centrifuge model consisted of a mildly sloping deposit tested in a rigid container, (2) LEAP-RPI-2020 which investigated the seismic response of a sheet-pile retaining a liquefiable soil deposit, and (3) LEAP-GWU-2022 in which the centrifuge model also consisted of a sheet-pile retaining a liquefiable soil deposit but had a different sheet-pile embedment length and input motion characteristics.  The centrifuge experiments were conducted at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the University of California at Davis, Cambridge University (UK), Kyoto University (Japan), National Central University (Taiwan), Zhejiang University (China), Gustave Eiffel University (France), and Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (Korea). Specifically, more than 65 LEAP centrifuge experiments were conducted, and provided a comprehensive unique set of experimental data that quantify soil response and liquefaction in the presence of lateral spreading and soil-structure interaction.  The collaboration among these international centrifuge teams enabled the development of more coherent practice in geotechnical centrifuge testing. Gaussian process regression analyses were performed to assess the reproducibility and repeatability of the centrifuge experiments and also identify the trends, patterns and sensitivity of tested system responses to variability in initial conditions and input motions. The results showed that the reproducibility of centrifuge tests is complicated by the inherent variability in experimental conditions among the testing facilities. Nevertheless, the regression analysis demonstrated that the conducted tests have a high level of reproducibility once this variability is accounted for.  The collaboratory experimental efforts also included an extensive program of soil characterization and laboratory element tests.

A validation exercise was conducted for each LEAP. More than 10 numerical prediction teams (from the US, Europe and Asia) participated and submitted type B and thereafter type C predictions of the conducted LEAP experiments.  These predictions provided a comprehensive insight into the capabilities, performance and validity of (computational) soil liquefaction models in the presence of lateral spreading and soil-structure interaction.   Following each LEAP, a workshop was held to discuss the results of experiments and numerical simulations. The proceedings of the LEAP-2017 workshop have been published in an open-access format and have been widely accessed and used by the geotechnical engineering community. The proceedings of the LEAP-2020 and LEAP 2022 workshops are being published in a similar (open-access) format.  Also, the outcome of these LEAPS is being published in special issues of archival journals.  The data resulting from this project is being organized and will be archived on DesignSafe. From a broader perspective, this data is useful for: (1) future validation efforts, (2) other liquefaction research, and (3) in geotechnical modeling education. Eventually, the validation efforts and the experimental data of this project will help in the development and streamlining of the validation of numerical tools in the fields of geotechnical engineering. A total of five graduate (PhD) students were involved in the project at Rensselaer and received unique training opportunities spanning the experimental, analytical and numerical geotechnical fields (three of the students were females).  These students had also an opportunity to interact and collaborate with other students and research teams from the various international institutions of the LEAP collaboratory.


Last Modified: 04/20/2023
Modified by: Mourad Zeghal
